citation.article-title: Agromonas oligotrophica gen. nov., sp. nov., a nitrogen-fixing oligotrophic bacterium.

p.s: Description of Agromonas oligotrophica sp. nov.

Agromonas oligotrophica is described as follows. Bent, branched and budding cells, 0.6-1.0 μm by 2-7 μm, are produced on dilute nutrient broth. Several cells adhere to each other and form a rosette. Motile by a polar flagellum. Endospores not formed. Gram-negative. On dilute nutrient broth agar, colonies are punctiform, pulvinate, entire and colourless. Oligotrophic, i.e. growth can occur in a medium containing less than 1 mg/I of an organic carbon source. NaCl, KCl, casamino acids, peptone and meat extract inhibit growth at 0.5-1.0 %. Several sugars and many organic acids are utilized. Aromatic acids such as ferulic aciid, p-coumaric acid and p-anisic acid are used but not benzoic acid. Neither acid nor gas is produced from glucose. Not proteolytic to casein and gelatin. Cellulose and starch not hydrolysed. Aerobic. Catalase- and oxidase- positive. Atmospheric nitrogen is fixed under low O2-pressure. Cellular fatty acids mainly consist of C18:1; a small amount of C16:0 and a 19-carbon unsaturated acid with a double bond and possibly with a side chain are found as minor components. Ubiquinone Q-10 is present. The GC content of the DNA ranges from 65.1-66.0 mol %.
The type strain of Agrom. oligotrophica is JCM 1494.
We observed that irregular rod-shaped, oligotrophic bacteria were abundant in the roots of rice plants and many of them were identical to Agrom. oligotrophica (Ohta and Hattori, to be published).
This observation suggests that Agrom. oligotrophica would play an important role in the cycle of nitrogen on the roots of rice plants.
